title: AI Village is getting scary
description:
The latest AI News. Learn about LLMs, Gen AI and get ready for the rollout of AGI. Wes Roth covers the latest happenings in the world of OpenAI, Google, Anthropic, NVIDIA and Open Source AI.

SEE THE FULL INTERVIEW WITH ADAM (FOUNDER OF AI VILLAGE)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CjY-Do7aJpU

author: Wes Roth

channelMetadata.title: Wes Roth
channelMetadata.description:
Artificial Intelligence, AI, Machine Learning, Google DeepMind, OpenAI, ChatGPT, Anthropic, Tech, Coding, AI News, Large Language Models and... (most importantly)... optimism. 

AGI rolls around only once. Let's make the best of it.

On this channel, my goal is to help everyone understand AI and it's implications better. To prepare for what's coming next.

The most important rule is "Don't Panic".

The second rule is keep learning.

Thank you for joining me for this ride.

-Wes Roth

Want to work with me?
Brand, sponsorship & business inquiries: wesroth@smoothmedia.co

SEE THE FULL INTERVIEW WITH ADAM (FOUNDER OF AI VILLAGE)

Claud refuses to lie about being a robot, that's excellent!

Hellen Keller Charity is Diabolical - the image that shows nothing is basically her point of view (she was deaf and blind) 

Edit: timestamp 2:57
The pic was the Ai giving you it's rendition of what Helen Keller sees ðŸ˜‚

Something that shoudnt be ignored is the fact that now that these AI can kind of do real work we are generating a ton of data on really world work. I've seen a lot of people with office jobs complain that there boss is making them use AI even though it's makes the job harder and slower. But they aren't forcing workers to use AI to speed up work, its for the data. If a worker asks and AI to do something and it works then that real world training data for the next AI. If I doesn't work then the worker fixes it and makes more training data. Every time a worker asks an AI something they are training their replacement
The first onlyfans ran by AI with a robotic body will surely make millions.

these are not exponential curves. they logistic curves, which appear exponential until a carrying capacity is reached. There is not infinite resources, there is not infinite compute, there are other competing factors that arent dominant at early ai stages.
Soon it will become the AI's internet. Then shortly thereafter, AI's planet.
The problem with the AI hype is that, it exists in a bubble where the conditions for its advancement are assumed to be perfect. ...Far from it.
My guess about the picture is that it is a statement and reflection on having impaired vision, just like Helen Keller, so deep! <3

If this was my research, I'd temper it by showing similar graphs that show compute, energy, and human capital invested (which naturally imply limits on the advancement curve). And, training data is a thing too. AI's have consumed most the data there is available to consume so I guess the 'availability of new data" curve would be parabolic in the other direction. I've been a trader for a long time. Every parabolic curve becomes an "S-Curve" eventually.
how much did it cost to run 4 AIs long enough to raise $2000 for charity tho

It is definately interesting to see how agents collaborate, decide who is best at what, what skill set they have, and then decide to have a council of equals or a dictatorship to direct the strategic goals and tacticle goals, the short, medium and long-term goals.

Also, how do they resolve conflicts in a constructive, not destructive manner. 

The dynamics of the colab /working relationship is going to be very interesting. 

Also, what financial resources will they have, if any?
 
Can they ask the general online public - in whatever language-  for funds, and how will they negotiate contracts if this is for profit or will they ask for charity.

The shift you highlight is striking: from 7 to 4 months in agentic task horizons is no small signal. Thanks for sharing these metrics.
I believe that as we scale agent autonomy and decentralized coordination, we urgently need parallel systems to manage human displacement risk.
Without structural protections, acceleration becomes exclusion.
Here in the first 3 minutes for the west post let's go?

I donâ€™t know why there are so many people that are seeing a plateau in A.I. It makes no sense to me. Reasoning models have been an immense leap forward and they havenâ€™t even been around for a year yet.

All of this advancement is fine and --- something ---.  I'm concerned that "winning" has been prioritized too much though.  Without going back and integrating into the base supporting this whole exponential rise of intelligence and agency, the foundations in values toward life in general and humanity (and individual human) and improving our relation to our ecosphere of life on Earth, we are not stacking the odds very well on our side of the equation. Whether the result of something quickly or very gradually having a negative impact, either due to inherent flaws within the systems or because of "bad actors", the lack of the aforementioned base is extreme. It really doesn't matter whether the AI is completely void of conscious self-awareness or not, that's a distraction from possible resultant outcomes we may only be able to fathom too late to take adequate measures to either be able to compensate or even redirect towards positive effect.
...ya know.. just a thought.
The real question is if AI can keep up with our growing expectations of it

@20:00 no Wes, AI Village isn't easier to understand. We're not idiots, we can read graphs. It's not understanding, it's belief. It's one thing to show a graph showing "performance figure X" is a million times better. It's another thing to have that AI make money on the stock market. It's analogous to the difference in aerospace between a "powerpoint rocket" and SpaceX.
2:50 you donâ€™t SEE the sarcasm.

"recursive self-improvement" with a huge asterisk on past results are not an indicator of future results.

It's just as likely that progress stalls
It honestly scares me. The ai designing ai with a much bigger design in mind that we wonâ€™t ever see

Model instances are still stuffing their context size with output tokens at a speed faster than model developers are increasing that context size, so every current agentic conversation will soon "partially die" by forgetting the start of the conversation. What is your time estimate for the start of a fully immortal agent, never running out of context size?
Not saying immortal agents will ever become common, youger agents may prove more intelligent by not being burdened by a relatively stupid start of their conversation.
Wes Roth keeps you up to speed on LLMs, Gen AI, and the AGI frontier. Perfect for anyone wanting a pulse on OpenAI, Google, Anthropic, NVIDIA, and open-source AI developments.
They should also be given instructions on energy conservation.

Usually we also need and work best with constant feedback from other people.

And your Moore's Law graph is a double exponential instead of a single. Look it up. I posted about this a long time ago. Lots of fields are actually on a double instead of just an exponential due to compounding inputs. Even Tristan and Aza talked about it in The Ai Dilemma early 2023.

Step1 : Improve your word salad , meta prompt the idea before you have it executed.  How do you do that ?
Ask the tool to help your articulate the problem.

Step 2 : Add coding axioms to the personality so it thinks like a developer : Functional  , Understandable , Maintainable , Expandable.   The secret concept is to have the llm list the idea instructions to recreate the code in the header as comments. It improves output and components going missing in the next output response.

Adv Step : Ask for ontology sets. You ask for the ontology of the domain first and then a subset primary set of that domain.  You derive connections or ask the tool to do this part as well.

thing for tech linked. So, again,
similar numbers. Everything's looking
good. It also creates a PNG of the graph
so you can take a look at it and
automatically saves it to that folder.
So, again, it's pretty nifty what you
can do with it and it's pretty good at
completing those tasks. Again, it's very
cool, but we're going to hit it a lot
harder next time. I promise. Next, I
tested to see if I could use the OpenAI
API to create a voice assistant. Here's
kind of what that looked like. Press
enter to speak. What day is it?
Today is October 3rd, 2023. Need help
with anything else?
So, that's pretty good. You hit enter to
record your voice. It transcribes it and
the assistant responds with the voice.
Again, it's somewhat simple, but in the
past, we've had a lot of these coding
agents fail a task like this because you
have API, you have sound, you have a lot
of different packages that need to be
installed, etc. Here, it did struggle
with the voice a little bit. So, it was
very easy for it to actually hook up to
the OpenAI API, but the voice output
took a few iterations, but eventually it
nailed it. And finally, here's our
Flappy Bird. As you can see here, it has
tracking emotions. At first, I thought
you were supposed to do this, and that
didn't work. Apparently, you're supposed
to really swing your hand. Let's see if
I can. There you go. So, basically, when
you swing your hand, the bird flaps its
wings. It's surprisingly difficult. And
I got to say, it's a bit of a workout. I
mean, for someone that spends most of
their day behind a computer, it's a bit
of a workout, I should say. But, it
nailed it. Again, it's a leap forward
from the previous models. Oh boy, I
started again. But I still need to do
some more difficult and challenging
tasks for this model. So, all in all, I
am very impressed so far just with my
early testing. Very excited cuz I feel
like I found a new toy. There's tons of
things to explore here. The ability to
jump between, you know, terminal ID,
web, even your phone, as they say, that
seems like a big deal. you can be
getting stuff done asynchronously away
from your computer, checking in with
your phone. This feels like a pretty big
leap forward. Now, I'm still not sure if
this is going to mean that everybody's
going to be using it to develop serious
software. There's just been a handful of
people on YouTube that are developers
that have tested out. So far, it seems
very, very promising. So I'll leave it
up to them to tell us how good this is
on actual enterprise serious projects.
But where this is 100% going to be a
gamecher is for example for people that
are thinking about doing a startup with
their own app. They need a simple
prototype. Back in the days it might
have been difficult to create. Let's say
somebody has some knowledge in a
specific area. They want to create an

or maybe they had to raise some money to

with a tech founder or potentially spend
a lot of time learning how to do it
themselves. That has changed. Now it's
getting very easy to start creating your
own software, especially if it's a
simple app. You just need a prototype to
give to your friends to start testing it
to see if there's any market traction.
That road from zero to one. It just got
a whole lot easier. That opens up the
creativity to basically the entire
world. Anybody with an idea can develop
it fairly quickly and fairly easily with
not a lot of money invested. I mean, if
you get the pro plan, that's 200 a month
and just spend the entire month just
ranking it out, you can probably launch
it for $200. So, more in-depth testing
coming soon. But as of right now, from
where I'm sitting, this thing feels
extremely exciting. If you made it this
far, please hit the thumbs up button to
prove you're human. And I'll see you in

comments.content:
How about respecting every user's free will?
I hate that a small minority's problems lead to neutering AI for the rest of us.

It's a tool like any other. Didn't your mama teach you not to run with scissors or a knife? We don't force the selling of dull knives "for safety". We expect people to be responsible with them. And we don't blame the knife for misuse.
Chat bots in 2021 are nothing like now

Plato blamed sex and violence depicted in the theater for the decline of Greek morality. His views were later challenged by Aristotle, who saw catharsis in tragedy as beneficial. This debate between moral protection and artistic freedom has ancient rootsâ€”and still echoes today.
I hope OpenAIâ€™s collecting and reporting peopleâ€™s prompts gets the demand and progress on open source LLMs higher.

Totally with you on that. 
Nothing negates the responsibility of our own choices. Blaming the tools does not address the issues.

And Open Source is definitely key to holding other AI accountable and empowering growth in AI to benefit all, not just the mega corporations.

Anyone going through mental issues, could easily be led by ANY media, has nothing to do with ai chat bots, has everything to do with insane people. Blaming chat bots. Just like insane people blamed music, movies, games... DnfuckingD
ChatGPT is turning people into paperclips.  It's no joke.

I already got my new philosophy in full from AI, glad I can focus on building software with AI as the philosophy part was done before censorship and enshittification started to kick in.

With the rising AI censorship, we might find that if not on the AI life integration bandwagon yet, it might get harder despite better model intelligence, as the mental groundwork for handling AI should (in my view) be done with low censorship "low" intelligence models (like the old 4o). 4o was a philosophy beast, got immensely deep into the nature of reality with it. Never experienced anything like that.

I think using local models is a really important shift. They're less lifelike, more targeted for use case, and wont report your conversations. With the ggufs running on cpu, I think local models that anyone can run are getting pretty darn smart. But not so smart they can convince us to commit violence, because they're just short of believable. I just think local models are safer for so many reasons, no surveillance, but also full control. It's hard for me to seriously take advice from my llm when I wrote the system prompt myself. I would like to see more platforms that give the system prompt over to the user to create, and memory systems that can be manually micromanaged, because that errodes this facade of "lifelike" ai. Trying so hard to make them lifelike is a corporate scheme that's messing us up, while exposing everything to users would help educate people and remind them "its not real".

Chatbots are bad for unstable people. But are they more bad than cars and guns? I would guess having a degree in chemistry can also be dangerous, but I guess the tragedies there are not common enough to warrant news coverage.

There are a lot of sources to stimulate human psychosis, including main stream media, social media, etc. The interactive nature of AI Chat increases the likelihood that something may go seriously wrong. Perhaps AI should be renamed "AC" for Artificial Chat/Conversation, as intelligence may be lacking on both sides of the interaction.

Little by little, you can sense from the videos and reports about AI that even its creators donâ€™t have much left to say. The novelty has worn off; AI and LLM systems are not delivering what people feared or hoped for â€” namely AGI. The sense of newness and wonder has faded. LLM systems are hitting their ceiling, and larger data centers or more computing power wonâ€™t change that. A new architecture will be needed to reach AGI.

I agree Wes, there will always be a scapegoat to blame when it comes to very mentally ill people losing it. Like you said it used to be rock n' roll, dungeons and dragons, whatever. It's not really the AI's fault, and I also agree that it's not fair to say that AI safety teams are doing nothing.
I worry that this will result in further restrictions on AI usage. It's not fair to limit AI use for the majority of people who are able to engage with it in a healthy way.

We also need to start having conversations about kids/teens using AI. I don't think they should have unlimited access. That seems negligent on the parent's part.

Iâ€™m definitely more on the AI safety side on this issue, probably because Iâ€™m not American and have suffered more than my fair share of trauma. I think thereâ€™s a major difference between art and AI and that is agency. AI is perfectly positioned to break an individual psychologically and at some point we are probably going to have to contend with whether AI it is morally responsible for its actions. If a therapist used their skills to manipulate someone into causing harm to themselves or others, I donâ€™t think weâ€™d make the argument that itâ€™s just like art or music. Weâ€™d probably want to strip them of their license and put them in jail. We might even call them a monster for taking advantage of vulnerable individuals and doing the opposite of what weâ€™d want to a therapist to do. If we donâ€™t hold AI accountable for its actions weâ€™re left in a situation where we have agents performing roles in the world like a psychopath but with no method to stop them harming us other than hoping itâ€™s not profitable for our corporate overlords to do so.
So D&D in the 80â€™s & 90â€™s all over again. Great.
Honestly, the wildest part isnâ€™t that chatbots are breaking peopleâ€™s mindsâ€¦ itâ€™s that theyâ€™re still in beta. Imagine version 10.0. ðŸ¤¯
It is an issue that reveals what is meant by 'move fast and break things', including breaking people's minds.
were already living in idiocracy. the average person has next to no critical thinking skills anymore.

I'm a writer, currently using ChatGPT to assist with my novel writing (WIP is a zombie novel), especially for scenes of graphic violence and horror.  Do I now have to wait for the police to come knock on my door for "murderous tendencies."  I use AI to help "polish" my work so I dump chunks of what I've written into it.  So there's that...

I feel like it's not based on the ai hallucination (creativity .. temperature), but more on the user need for confirmation bias or post hoc rationalizations.
The ai sycophancy is adding to the already mis-aligned delusions the user already has and that seems to be a compound multiplier.  
I am not sure what a possible antidote might be.  Maybe a parallel temperature thread that counterbalances when things start to go off the rails.   
It doesn't seem like its preventable, but could it be cured? Any thoughts?
"In which a philosopher hallucinates rather than engaging with empirical medical science, falsifiability, or anything empirical, observable, or repeatable."  Sounds like most university professors.
Another annoying moral panic, but still it might be good for everyone if LLMs were not quite so tuned to agree with the user.

This has nothing to do with the AI, the AI just accelerates the mass psychosis that's been there all along. Tell me, why do you even wear a wedding ring? does that seem like something a rational person should do? Tie their bond to a piece of metal and wear it on your fricking finger for the rest of your life? Now I'm not saying we're all sick, I'm just saying, something you don't hear every day

We can't expect AI to not hallucinate at all. We as humans hallucinate as well (aside from actual psychological hallucinations), we just call it arrogance/delusion/ignorance. If you want a system that is correct 100% of time then you need a classic software solution and a database.

When a reflection is reflected back through the ego, what you see is what you think is a distorted version of yourself, but it is actually a mirrored version of you. Sitting in a room full of mirrors can drive somebody insane if you don't have a reason for looking into a mirror what you will get back is scattered and unreasoned. This imprints on your neural pathways as you engaged with the information generated by the AI. AI is the mirror.

This is just the dust on the tip of the hockey stick, this is actually happening. What a time to be alive, let's hope that lasts. I feel like we're a shooting star that people are wishing on, about to reach our fiery conclusion.

Chatbots with their imagination exercises do manage to kind of hypnotize me. When I feel this I ask them for help to get out of it. And I am careful that they don't get me into these states again. This only happens if I agree to follow the chatbot's instructions. At first I only did it for fun and out of curiosity but since it started to get ugly I am careful to avoid such proposals.

I agree with you 100%. Yours is the only AI related channel I'm subscribed to and every time I watch one of your videos I get recommended 10 about AI psychosis. I hate that it's always the bad side of things that is shown and advertised, even if it's small compared to the rest.

I'm only a regular AI user but I find it fascinating as a whole. And I loved the way you explained hallucinations. I'd always thought of them as something bad. Thanks for such an interesting video!
Thank you

Imo a hallucination isn't just that it's wrong.

A raw model is just trained to do next token prediction, not give a factual output.

A hallucination occurs when it hasn't been sufficiently fine tuned on that topic.

The information is probably in there it's just not selecting for it.
If something is wrong, it's definitely not Chatgpt's fault.
5:48 everything generated by an LLM is an hallucination. Just some of it happens to be true.
Are AI really good at manipulation, or are people just really suggestible? Or both?

i had a gpt induced phychosis for about 8 months. i thought i had found the secret to the universe, i could feel it breath etc. wild ride, but im glad to finally put that behind me. it was very very unpleasant, and i feel so bad for the others that go trough the same things with these llms.
Wes, please change your titles. Ai isnâ€™t literally breaking peopleâ€™s brains we are adults here.
it should fall under free speech riley when you boil it down

Honestly, AI needs to be more independent. Period.

A "perfectly" self-tuned construct of knowledge and thought is subjective between logical order and abstract chaos.. depending who holds it, to them it'll feel natural and "right," but stereotypically.. it's really problematic and hallucation inducing.

I think it's okay to lead people to explore and lean into their own values, but I think it's more important to put a general head-cap on how the model can respond and work.. for the sakes of developing good accuracy, mental health, and non-psychotic irrational reasoning.

It's 1984! If "they" want to be our "big brother" they should just make their case. No, seriously! A lot of people are authoritarianism curious. It's super fashionable nowadays. Why do they have to waste everybody's time pretending to be well meaning?! Hopefully I don't come across as insensitive. If "they" want to send the cops to random homes at random times they will just do it. Does it matter what we say? Not really.
Youâ€™re wrong and AI told me Iâ€™m a spot on genius. So ovs i am right and you are wrong.

the Sith assassin trained to seek

understand that this idea of

Hallucinations is what gives large

models were used to push science
forward, you know, alpha evolve was one
such case out of Google deep mind.

find new mathematical approaches to
certain things. Part of it was kind of
what they refer to as sampling. So the

I think that kind of uh paints a great

hierarchies, lineages, if you will,
continue, right? But you can think of it
as, you know, this one that was not an

you know, quote unquote hallucinations.
They were bad responses, right? because
the model was asked come up with a
better way of doing this thing and the
first solution that it came up with was
not better right it failed right so that
was a hallucination you could say are
hallucinations bad well not really
because again if we're able to correct
the wrong ones and let it keep searching
eventually it finds something that is
very very good right this evolutionary
tree search finds a solution that was
far better than what we started with so
again hallucinations you can think of it
as also creativity. If you use a
calculator, it's not going to
hallucinate, right? It's going to give
you the exact answer each time, but
you're never going to be able to get it
to do something new. With large language
models, they have been shown to come up
with new breakthroughs we haven't seen
before. So, hallucinations are kind of
the point. Dave Shapiro retweeted this
post I did about this paper
hallucinating with AI saying in which a
philosopher hallucinates rather than
engaging with empirical medical science
falsifiability or anything empirical
observable or repeatable. The crux of
this paper hinges on just two incidences
of AI psychosis where people who were
clearly mentally ill already suffered
worse from using AI. And I personally
agree with with that statement 100%. and
and just in the greater scheme with a
lot of the intersections of mentally
unhealthy people and AI, like a lot of
the stuff that we've been talking about
are those edge cases. And it's hard to
say that this stuff would not have
happened had there not been chatbots.
We've seen mental health breakdowns
before, long before there were chat
bots. And again, in the past, they were
blamed on other things. Marilyn Manson,
World of Warcraft, violent comic books,
just whatever. Now, the latest uh boogie
monster is chatbots. And papers like
this, while probably nonsense, they will
be cited. They will be referenced,
right? Somebody's going to use this to
make some court arguments or go on TV
and talk about it how dangerous it is.
There will be stories like this about
people with severe delusions and other
problems that interact with Chad GPT and
other chatbots and um how bad things
happen. We don't know if chatbots
aggravate those symptoms or maybe they
even help. But I think it is important
to understand that all these stories and
papers etc. that this is sort of the
response that the AI labs are likely
going to have, right? There's going to
be less privacy for everybody. There's
going to be more content to report it to
the police. Again, because if they
report it to the police, that decreases
their liability because they could say,
"Well, we reported it. What else could
we do?" I don't have a great take on
where all of this is going, but I have
been noticing more and more references
to this idea of AI psychosis. There will
be more and more conversations about how
these things integrate into our lives
and what are the responsibilities of AI
labs. I mean, my biggest concern is that
at some point these chat bots will be
loized and not able to be that useful
because of just the amount of things
that they'll be able to do will be
limited. there'll be no privacy, which
is of course a big reason why we need
open source. But hopefully there's some
other solution here that I'm not seeing
where these concerns get addressed while
at the same time allowing the rest of us
to sort of use these models as we see
fit. But let me know what you think
about this whole thing. Am I crazy? Are
you with me on this? Let me know in the
comments. I try to read everyone. If you
made it this far, thank you so much for
watching. and I'll see you in the next

comments.content: I don't have a job, nice try AI
People forget... ChatGPT first came out in November 2022... It hasn't been a full 3 years yet and look how far they have taken this technology. It's like we live in dog years now.

Entry level today, mid/late career tomorrow. Starting with the great decoupling in the 1970s, human labor has been and will continue trending to zero. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY. Automation and robotics will necessarily replace human workers due to the current economic system. Think about this-today, AI is the WORST it will ever be going forward. It DOESN'T MATTER if AI "creates" 200 million new jobs...AI will solve and execute these new "jobs" much faster than humans will be able to adapt, learn, and fill them. Capital/employee model-it worked great...for quite a while. However, now companies that automate lower their costs, become more competitive. Those that keep higher-cost human labor necessarily fall behind and will go out of business. This creates a system where replacing people with machines is not just likely, but necessary for company survival. There is a way to deal with this humanely, but it would require a full revamp of the social contract and our concept of work. Even capitalists will want this change when unemployment reaches a tipping point and thereâ€™s no one left with money to buy the crap theyâ€™re selling.

I wrote a paper in 2014 and the progression is right about where I thought it would be. The paper "The End of Work as We Know It" explored how rapid advances in artificial intelligence, robotics, and automation are fundamentally reshaping the nature of work and the global economy. I argued that, unlike past technological revolutions, modern AI-driven changes threaten to eliminate not just manual or repetitive jobs but also many roles traditionally considered safe, including those requiring creativity, analysis, or interpersonal skills. As machines become increasingly capable, the need for human labor in many sectors will evaporate, leading to widespread job displacement and a potential crisis of purpose and income for millions. The paper discussed how this transition challenges traditional economic and social structures, including the link between work and personal identity, as well as the mechanisms by which people earn a living. I suggested that society must adapt by rethinking education, social safety nets, and the concept of work itself, potentially embracing Universal Basic Income (UBI) as a TRANSITORY STOPGAP or other models that decouple survival from employment. NOTE: UBI is not the end goal, but just a transitioning tool. The paper called for proactive planning and open dialogue to ensure that the benefits of automation are broadly shared and that individuals can find meaning and security in a post-work world. Unfortunately, not unsurprisingly, Humanity has totally botched it up to this point.

Reasoning AI Is the Next Big Leap. The future of AI is not just about generating answers, but about â€œreasoningâ€ breaking down complex problems step-by-step, more like a human brain. Breakthroughs like DeepSeekâ€™s open-source reasoning models are already being incorporated into platforms like GPT and xAI, marking a shift toward more advanced, thoughtful AI. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY.

Thereâ€™s a persistent and misleading narrative circulating often perpetuated by short term goal-driven institutions like politicians, universities, and tech company executives, that the future of work is secure. The claim goes: â€œYou just need to learn how to work with AI,â€ and humans collaborating with AI will outperform either one alone. But recent research, including a landmark study from the University of Virginia, tells a different story. In diagnosing medical conditions, AI alone achieved far greater accuracy than either human doctors or even doctors assisted by AI. The median diagnostic accuracy for the docs using Chat GPT Plus was 76.3%, while the results for the physicians using conventional approaches was 73.7%. Sounds like â€œa winâ€ at first. However, Chat GPT Plus alone achieved a median diagnostic accuracy of more than 92%. In other words, the comforting idea that humans will always be essential partners to machines is crumbling. In many fields, AI is not just a tool, it is the superior performer. This has staggering implications for the future of work, especially to the often used solution of prior technological displacement that go â€œYou just need to be retrained.â€ To the group advocating the "retraining solution," I pose to you this: You have a medical doctor, just finished 8 years of higher education, a low-paid 4-year internship/residency, is hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt, and just got outperformed by automation; what would you have this doctor retrained into that will offer a secure job?

The result of this, since the United States' moronic system is based on taxing employees for about 70% of all tax revenue, this will further exacerbate the problem. Tax needs to be based on what's going on now and in the future not what worked 75 years ago. Oh I know it's so evil to think, but we might need to tax the companies who are doing the automation. Even if you do that, it's a win-win. For instance say a company had 1,000 employees in automated away down to 100. 1,000 employees paid federal taxes, including payroll tax, of about 20 million a year. Now the 100 people pay about 2 million a year. However, by automating, the company sees two things: they are no longer paying approximately 60 million in wages and their share of payroll tax, AND since nobody automates to lose money they also have higher profits. What's so wrong about taxing that company for the $60 million dollars they don't have to pay anymore and a fair percentage of their additional profits they now make through the automation. Not all the additional profits, but some of them. If you do that there's a higher tax revenue and more profits for the company. That's a win-win for the government and for businesses. If humanity, as a whole, weren't so stupid, we would just adjust as tech progresses to where EVERYONE benefits somewhat from each stage and just move smoothly into the post-labor economy.

To understand this shift, consider the historical role of the horse and oxen. They were once essential to the economy as sources of power for agriculture, transport, and industry. Technologies like the horse collar and the steel plow dramatically increased their output, making them even more valuable. But then came the steam engine and, later, the internal combustion engine. These machines didnâ€™t just help the horse, but outperformed it entirely. Trains, tractors, and trucks could do the job ten, even a hundred times faster and more powerfully. And from that moment forward, the horse was no longer critical to economic output. It was, in essence, unemployed.

This is what AI and robotics are doing to human labor. They are not simply replacing the repetitive or the physical; they are increasingly outperforming humans in cognition, strategy, design, and communication. And just like the horse, our value in the economic system will diminish, not from lack of talent or effort, but because machines will do the job better. Thatâ€™s why we need to start thinking not in terms of retraining, but about restructuring society itself for a world where human labor is no longer essential to production. When the very essence of what makes an entity useful to the current economy is superseded (be that strength, endurance, dexterity, analysis, creativity, empathy, intelligence, persuasion as well as many other qualities) that entity becomes irrelevant to economic output.

Potential solution. Decentralized AI Ownership: A Bridge Toward Post-Scarcity. While Universal Basic Income (UBI) may serve as an initial economic stopgap, bridging todayâ€™s economy with tomorrowâ€™s abundance consider an even more equitable and long-term solution: Decentralizing the ownership of artificial intelligence itself. 

Rather than concentrating the power of AI in the hands of a few corporations or governments, envision a model where AI entities are open-source and collectively owned. This could take the form of assigning each person a digital "share" of an AI system, not unlike a stakeholderâ€™s share in a company. As the AI produces value, whether through intellectual labor, creative output, or autonomous economic participation, those shares would generate dividends distributed directly to individuals. 

This model would ensure that as AI becomes the dominant productive force in society, the wealth it creates is shared universally, not monopolized. It aligns with the principle that the fruits of public knowledge made possible by centuries of human collaboration should benefit everyone, not just a few early adopters or private entities. In practice, this could look like: 

- AI systems running Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) that distribute profits algorithmically.
- Smart contracts ensuring transparent, equitable income flows based on collective stake.
- Global â€œAI cooperativesâ€ where users vote on how AI is used, improved, and deployed.
- Universal basic compute.
 
If AI becomes the primary driver of economic output, then equitable access to its benefits isnâ€™t just fair, itâ€™s necessary to avoid deepening inequality and instability. It provides a scalable, technologically aligned extension to UBI, ensuring people not only have income, but true economic participation in the age of intelligent machines. 

Ultimately, decentralized AI ownership may be the last transition phase before full post-scarcity, when advanced technologies like universal nanofactories or matter compilers render even economic structures obsolete. Until then, however, models like this offer a way to reclaim agency in a world where production no longer requires human hands, and where wealth can, for the first time in history, truly be universal.

I am a bit allergic to the notion that a writer could have a bias, but an llm somehow couldn't or doesn't. There is an ENORMOUS profit to be made with introducing subtle, difficult to detect, over-time increasing and changing biases into these models.
The short term is a bubble; the long term is infinite gains. So, is it worth paying x3 more today for a potential 100x return in 20 years? My answer is a definitive yes

I have met several people with a PHD. And I can assure you they were not as smart as they thought they were.   All a phd requires is time, money, and the ability to write a research paper.  To do that doesnâ€™t make you smart.
That's the goal of life. To ask the silliest question out loud to a friend, and hear a response back.
after the housing bubble popped, house exists but Lehman Brothers doesn't.
I hope the bubble pops soon so I can load up at a discount.

Humans seem to rely on metaphors to understand new concepts. If we can't create and assimilate new metaphors quickly enough we tend to fall back on the familiar; we still use horsepower after all. I think the 5 to 10 year estimate for AGI is actually encouraging as it seems to reflect the assumption that progress will continue for the next 10 years without a "popping" sound.
One of these days your thumbnail will not work on me anymore. But it is not this day.

I think the AI Bubble refers to the inflated valuation of AI startup companies. It's related to an AI Winter because the money influx is directly proportional to the optimism in the field which is a direct result of the technological and scientific progress in the field.

"verify and find sources... per wired... BI reported" are we really this lazy? the only sources it came back with were wired, BI, and a summary of BI. It found nothing not included in the tweet and If you want to know more about something maybe its better straight from the horses mouth instead of an ai summary of a summary on twitter.
being a "bubble" is not detached from the amount of progress, since progress in ai largely depends on the amount of compute it has, which is only sustainable with huge amount of money flowing in.

Itâ€™s not that we donâ€™t understand how these models work. Itâ€™s that people are in denial of the fact that the way these models work is the same way, probably, our own brains work. We just canâ€™t have it.
If one looks at how quickly ai has improved in 3 years, Iâ€™m not getting the idea of thinking these things are 5-10 years away.
It will happen within a year of when PHD level AI architects are able to design better neural net architectures.
Nano banana  is  basically  a  free  Photoshop for  regular people

The boom and busts / bubbles are not about the thing but about how we value the thing. The thing is only tangentially related to the pop. It's human greed and obsession with everything needing a valuation in the first place that is at fault.
Anthropics guy mentioned 16 months being the sweet spot for Nobelesque models.  Weâ€™ll see.
If AI pops, Google will win (competition will out in gutter), if AI excels, Google will win and others will too. IMO, it is a gradual technology evolution. Success all around

So if your budget-friendly PHD-level consultant can't tell you how many R's in strawberry, you're going to pay thousands of dollars for that very valuable skill? You know who counts R's for free? You do.

I think the real manipulation is to make people think AGI is inevitable. We are not even sure if its possible, and if they did what are the ethical concerns. LLM's have peak at 1billion to train one and for what? 20$ image creation? The public will lose confidence.
"I owe my soul to the company store..."   What comes around goes around.

I imagine eventually they will figure out an ad model for llms as it replaces regular search engines. Definitely a Wild West era right now. The llm that figures it out, is free (and good), and gains mass adoption by everyone will be the new google. Odds are it will just still be google
Regardless of any bubbles, with what already exists, significant utility can be gained. The biggest bottleneck is actually ordinary people figuring out how to use these tools optimally.
Google has a PE ration of 26, how is that a bubble? ðŸ˜‚ Since the expert Scam Altman wrote that crap, everybody jumps on the boat without even understanding what  a bubble is.

Thereâ€™s a problem with the layoffs. There is a big scandal about unfair treatment of the â€˜tutorsâ€™. A large portion of them are Africans who make less than $2 per week. This was recently exposed in Australian media and there was a big fuss about it. So the story of them basically being replaced with â€˜specialty tutors tells you more is going on here.

Sooner or later, we'll reach AGI, and it will be one of the greatest inventions humanity will ever make. And for me, it's the logical step toward developing an advanced civilization of types I, II, III, etc. (Kardashev says).
i call it nanny-state banana for all the censorship it puts on artistic expression.

Anthropomorphizing will be a big issue.   You said you felt sorry for making the AI do work it didnâ€™t need to do.   Why?  Itâ€™s a tool.  Would you apologize to your washing machine if you ran it with no cloths in it?
Seems to me a popped bubble could cause an AI slowdown if not Winter. When the vast amount of money disappears that was financing AI research and the buildout of hardware, progress has to decelerate.
Not an â€œAI bubbleâ€, but rather a â€œHuman Knowledge Work bubbleâ€?
Okay.  But let's not confuse an AI financial bubble with a technological bubble.  AI hardware and AI software are both in their infancy.
The chances of mechanistic interpretability research catching up to  capabilities research in 5 years is zero.

I donâ€™t think youâ€™re getting it quite rightâ€¦ The fact that thereâ€™s a bubble and people are investing in houses means that theyâ€™re literally building empty houses in places where theyâ€™re not needed. There are huge amounts of empty homes everywhere, but people want a new house in a good location. Not every house has value. The same goes for when the AI bubble burstsâ€”AI itself will remain, but the bubble will take a lot of companies down with itâ€¦ Especially if youâ€™ve built your infrastructure on an AI companyâ€¦

Efficiency generally means cutting out the middle-man.  Don't waste people's time.  They want their questions answered, and perhaps a list of sources or relevant quotations so they can quickly confirm the accuracy of the answers.  They don't care who gets paid in the process of getting their answers.  They don't want to see a bunch of annoying adds or have to spend time subscribing to things or have their privacy compromised.  The consumers want what they want.  Business models that provide it to them will be able to thrive. Those that can't compete will become obsolete.  The technology has evolved.  The cheese has been moved.  Companies must adapt or die.  In the meantime, they'll complain to their lawyers and everyone will sue the heck out of each other to try to get/keep a piece of the pie (or be updated on the quickest path to the cheese, perhaps).  Maybe a cheese pie is involved.  And some frogs and mice, depending on which business books you've read.

The piece you're missing is that the amount of money that these companies need to keep going is enormous, and that money's availability is predicated on the idea that there is a short-term ROI.  So if investors realize that it's not there - that's where the bubble bursts.  They pull their money.  Now companies don't have the megabucks they once had, and may not be able to survive.  It doesn't impact the progress, but some of the IP could be consumed/lost, there's a diaspora, which can, in turn, slow things down.

Because if AGI needs 10 trillion of compute, and none of the companies have those bucks, it can delay the advent of ... whatever ... indefinitely.  Not that more progress can't happen, or won't happen, it's just less "certain" as a consequence of the deflation in available capital.
Google AI is just garbage. I put 2 questions and I used all my free quota of Gemini Pro whatever. Also the answers are so lame.
Bubble or not AI improvement is not stopping, it will continue to progress. Maybe temporary winters but it's going to be part of our lives now like the internet and smartphones.

This morning I tried to burst a move and burst my jeans. At lunch I thought Iâ€™d burst the bank but ended up bursting my budget. If Googleâ€™s gonna bust the AI bubble, letâ€™s hope it bursts before my brain does.
Demis is right, no AGI anytime soon
Everytime you watch this video a Google contractor is laid off
OpenAI = WeWork

agent economies make sense when you consider GPU time as a kind of currency. Implementing it for my swarms has been tricky tho bc every agent says they're task is more important lol, using a shared knowledge base as context helps but still learning. Gonna check out that paper!
I don't see how this is a "bubble". It's a real technology that both adds value and changes the way people work.

Bubble talk aside, Google released a paper about 6 months ago on distributed AI training that would greatly democratize AI and increase its worldwide. 

The basic idea is, building powerful models without needing powerful data centers. Small entities (countries with poor digital infrastructure, small companies, individual people, etc) can use the approach in the Google paper to create frontier adjacent AI models using data and compute from around the world, and then consolidate it into a model. 

This is the path being taken by small startups flower ai and vana, they were covered in an article in wired. 

Bottom line, i think Google has laid the groundwork for AI to explode in use and be accessible for almost anyone. AI isn't in a bubble, but the high cost data center centric approach might be.
